ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Acoustic tumor (Vestibular Schwannoma)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Unilateral progressive hearing loss, tinnitus, imbalance, disproportionately poor speech recognition, absent ABR, and CT confirmation of a mass in the IAM/CPA.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing sensitivity and configuration of hearing loss.
To assess speech recognition abilities and check for retrocochlear signs (rollover or disproportionately poor scores).
To evaluate the acoustic reflex arc for signs of retrocochlear pathology.
To assess neural integrity and screen for retrocochlear pathology given the asymmetric loss.
To visualize the internal auditory meatus and cerebellopontine angle for structural lesions.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The patient presents with a classic retrocochlear profile on the right side. Audiometry reveals a moderate-to-severe SNHL in the right ear with disproportionately poor speech recognition (0% / CNT). Acoustic reflexes are elevated or absent with right ear stimulation, and ABR shows no repeatable waves on the right despite high intensity stimulation. Imaging confirmed a mass filling the right IAM and extending into the CPA.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: moderate to severe SNHL (approx. 45-75 dB HL). Left ear: mild to severe SNHL commencing at 2000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: CNT (0% recognition); could not recognize monosyllabic words. Left ear: 88% recognition.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Left ear stimulation: normal. Right ear stimulation: elevated at 500 and 1000 Hz, absent at 2000 Hz.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.result_summary: Right ear: no repeatable tracings at high intensities (80-90 dB nHL). Left ear: normal absolute latencies for waves III and V.

tests.name: CT Scan
tests.result_summary: Mass filling the Internal Auditory Meatus (IAM) and extending approximately 1.5 cm into the Cerebellopontine Angle (CPA).

counseling_actions: Explain the discrepancy between pure tone thresholds and speech recognition (retrocochlear pathology)
Discuss ABR and acoustic reflex results indicating neural involvement
Review radiological findings confirming the presence of an acoustic tumor
Discuss referral to Otolaryngology/Neurosurgery for management

escalation.rationale_short: Confirmed acoustic tumor requiring surgical intervention.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor recovery and assess post-operative hearing status.

expected_outcome: At surgery, the tumor was found to fill most of the IAM and extended approximately 1.5 cm into the CPA.
